Description: Eleven fragments from the body and rim of a fine burnished black-topped brown pottery vessel. The largest fragment is part of the transition to the base and has one hole drilled through it for the purpose of mending in antiquity. The walls are very thin, and made of very fine Nile silt clay.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: British School of Archaeology, Egypt
Curator's comments: Type possibly like Black top brown BB31M in Brunton and Caton-Thompson 1928. Marked 5100 in pencil. Other fragments of this same vessel are registered as EA 90725 and include a rim fragment with several similar drill holes for mending.
Bibliographic references: Brunton & Caton-Thompson 1928 / The Badarian Civilisation and Predynastic Remains near Badari (6)
